警告：本文包含许多流行科幻小说和奇幻娱乐系列的剧透。

你知道，我正在写一篇关于一些实质性经济学内容的文章，写到一半时我意识到我原来的论文并没有真正得到数据的支持。因此，作为一个非常懒惰、理智诚实的作家，我决定搁置该帖子并写一些有趣和轻松的内容。我碰巧刚刚看了 HBO 权力的游戏衍生剧《龙之屋》新一季的第一集，所以我想我应该写一些关于特许经营权的文章。

我当然不是创作《星球大战》、《星际迷航》、《权力的游戏》等高质量大预算娱乐系列的专家。但我是他们的固执己见的消费者，据我所知，这就是你写这个主题真正需要的一切。

如今娱乐特许经营的基本事实是，几乎所有内容都是续集、翻拍或改编。亚当·马斯楚安尼 (Adam Mastroianni)的数据如下：

这种趋势也蔓延到了电视领域。从《龙之屋》和《风骚律师》等衍生剧，到《基地》和《幕府将军》等改编剧，现在大部分电视节目也都是基于成熟的媒体资产。

这一趋势背后的经济力量非常容易理解。创造新的娱乐特许经营权（或众所周知的 IP）是一项热门驱动的业务- 你真的无法提前知道观众会喜欢什么以及他们会忽略什么。因此，如果你从事的是热门业务，你唯一能做的就是制作一堆东西并希望人们喜欢它。但这本质上是一项有风险的业务。如果制作新系列的成本增加——就像电视行业那样，向“优质电视”的转变提高了制作价值的门槛——那么风险就更大了。

投资者不喜欢风险。媒体公司希望取悦投资者。因此，媒体公司的高管面临着巨大的经济压力，需要将不稳定的热门驱动商业模式转变为具有经常性收入的稳定、可预测的商业模式。这样做的方法就是坚持现有的作品——续集、翻拍以及已经流行的源材料的改编。特许经营的延续可以让您了解您的观众是谁以及您的电影或连续剧的表现如何。因此，它部分降低了娱乐业的风险。

在这个新的特许经营驱动的世界中，“如何制作一部好电影或电视剧？”的问题。改变一点。当然，讲故事、对话写作、表演、导演和制作等经典工具仍然至关重要（《权力的游戏》第八季展示了如果这些工具没有得到有效利用时会发生什么）。但当故事发生在现有的宇宙中时，什么才是好故事的问题就会改变。

在过去的一两年里，我看到娱乐特许经营公司在这方面做得非常正确和非常错误。当然，这里的“对”和“错”只是我自己的主观评价——我认为《星球大战》续集绝对是残暴的，但它们赚了很多钱。但我认为总的来说，我的观点并没有那么不寻常，随着时间的推移，我所说的“糟糕”的续集和改编往往会导致特许经营权的回报递减。例如，我现在并不知道有谁喜欢《星球大战》续集，而且我认为他们的叙事失败是人们对《游侠索罗》等电影兴趣如此薄弱的原因之一。

因此，我认为这里有一些原则有助于确定特许经营分期付款是为IP注入新的活力还是将其付诸东流。

前传的好与坏：“传说”的诱惑

继续特许经营的一种非常常见的方式是制作前传。仅举几个例子，包括《星球大战》前传、许多最近的《星际迷航》节目和《龙之屋》。但我注意到，虽然其中一些确实非常出色，但另一些则相当平庸。有什么不同？

我认为，一个很大的区别是前传是否专注于填补系列的“传说”。我认为传说是一个来自电子游戏的术语，指的是虚构世界的历史——故事本身没有展示的事件。

例如，在第一部《星球大战》电影中，有两次提到“克隆人战争”——一次是卢克问欧比旺“你参加了克隆人战争吗？”，另一次是莱娅说“你在克隆人战争中为我父亲服务”。克隆人战争”。除此之外，克隆人战争从未被提及——最初的星球大战电影从未告诉我们这些战争是关于什么的，或者双方是什么，或者谁赢了，甚至为什么他们被称为“克隆人战争”。它们只是故事之外存在的事件——星球大战虚构宇宙传说的一部分。

二十年后，当乔治·卢卡斯制作《星球大战》前传时，他将它们以克隆人战争为中心。在这样做的过程中，他将传说变成了故事——他实际上向我们展示了上述所有问题的答案。

这是平庸的。当然，《星球大战》前传经常有笨拙的对话和令人困惑的导演，但最终他们讲述的故事根本不如原版电影中的故事引人入胜。我认为，部分原因是前传专注于传说。它们都是为了向我们展示前三部电影只告诉我们的东西。

这造成了一个非常受限的故事。它迫使你达到一组预定的故事节拍。欧比旺必须在前传中为阿纳金·天行者服务，因为原版电影说他就是这么做的。但这两个角色之间的关系最终让人感到强迫和木讷。

以传说为中心的前传也让虚构的世界显得更小、更受限制。在第一部星球大战电影中，当你听到“克隆人战争”时，会给你一种神秘和冒险的感觉。让这些事件存在于故事的边界之外，会让观众觉得这是一个充满重大事件、强大的战士、戏剧性冲突等的宇宙。但当你把所有这些东西作为新故事的一部分在屏幕上展示时，虚构的宇宙开始感到局促和自足——你已经看到了这个宇宙中发生的所有重要事情，没有什么秘密需要探索。

它只是限制了想象力。每个孩子在观看第一部电影时，都会围坐在一起试图想象克隆人战争是什么，以及它们可能会是什么样子。他们几乎没有人想到他们会看起来像这样：

另一个很好的例子是《星际迷航：发现号》。 《星际迷航》的部分传说是，联邦很久以前曾与克林贡帝国发生过战争。发现向我们展示了那场战争。这一描述的执行极其笨拙，将克林贡人变成了奇怪的蜥蜴生物，与其他《星际迷航》系列中的描述几乎没有联系。

但更重要的是，这让粉丝们对《星际迷航》宇宙的想象少了一件。 （《星际迷航：企业号》也做了很多这样的事情，但那个节目执行得非常糟糕，我什至无法让自己观看它。）

我认为这就是为什么铁杆系列粉丝经常对前传感到兴奋——“天啊，我们要看到克隆人战争了！” ——但常常对结果感到失望。传说激发了粉丝的想象力，而前传中描绘的版本将不可避免地与大多数人的想象不同。这会导致失望。

最小化这个问题的一种方法是改编对原始故事不太重要的知识片段。这就是龙之家所做的。被称为龙舞的内战在《权力的游戏》情节中并不是很重要，也没有被太多提及。作为一名《权力的游戏》粉丝，我从来没有坐下来想象龙之狂舞，我敢打赌大多数其他粉丝也不会。因此，当它被描绘在屏幕上时，没有什么可矛盾的。

但尽管如此，尽管编剧和导演都很出色，《龙之屋》还是受到了与传说的束缚。首先，自从我阅读了 wiki 以来，我知道将要发生的一切。更一般地说，整个故事的重点是建立《权力的游戏》开头的世界。没有新的奇幻魔法类型，没有遇到奇怪的新民族，没有新的预言或文物等。故事的重点是不断地填补 GoT 现有的背景故事。

真的，我认为归根结底是这样的：好的虚构宇宙总是比故事更宏大。当你试图扩展故事以展示虚构宇宙中发生的每一个重要事件时，宇宙就会变得狭窄而狭小，没有留给你想象的空间。

现在请注意，填写有关世界的细节和填写有关人物背景故事的细节之间存在很大差异。以我们心爱的角色的年轻版本为主角的前传很好。原因是大多数粉丝无法真正想象出好的角色背景故事——他们需要专业作家来填补这些细节。人物背景故事并不限制想象力——它更像是闪回。

真正出色的前传的一个例子是《星际迷航：奇怪的新世界》，这是我最近最喜欢的《星际迷航》系列。它发生在柯克船长接管之前的原始企业号上，其中包括 20 世纪 60 年代《星际迷航》系列中的几个角色。

然而《奇异新世界》中讲述的故事却是新的。剧中发生的事情几乎没有在其他《星际迷航》节目中被提及——都是原创内容。我们可以看到斯波克和乌胡拉以及其他一些企业号船员是如何成为他们现在的样子的。但他们面临的外部挑战几乎都是全新的。

部分原因是该剧的剧集形式。但这很大程度上只是因为编剧有意识地决定扩大《星际迷航》的宇宙，而不是填充它。我们看到了全新的故事，比如与戈恩人的斗争，而角色之间的关系要么是新的，要么在 1960 年代的剧中只略有暗示。

这真是太神奇了。粉丝们喜欢《奇异新世界》 ，并且有充分的理由——它是多年来最好的《星际迷航》。可能是自 1999 年《深空 9》结束以来最好的一部。

不知何故，即使有史波克、乌呼拉和那艘古老的经典飞船，企业号仍然感觉像是在冒险进入伟大的未知世界。

这是我给特许经营商的第一条建议。不要把世界填满。扩大世界。

主题连续性：“颠覆”最好是小剂量

很多人花钱观看《星球大战》续集，但我认识的人几乎没有人记得它们或认为它们很好。唯一的例外是一小群铁杆人士，他们认为《最后的绝地武士》是一部伟大的电影。当你问他们为什么时，他们通常给出的理由是它“颠覆”了星球大战的传统主题。一个例子是，主角之一雷伊被告知她没有任何特殊或高贵的血统，不像原版电影中的卢克和莱娅。 1

但是——抱歉，最后的绝地迷们——谁在乎呢？仅仅因为一个比喻很有趣，并不意味着它的反面也会很有趣！关于一见钟情的故事通常很有趣。但一个关于两个人相遇、未能相爱、再也见不到对方的故事，并不一定会因为“颠覆”一见钟情的比喻而同样有趣。

小说中的主题“颠覆”大多是空洞的。有很多平庸的奇幻书籍试图通过让英雄成为——喘息来颠覆“命运英雄”的比喻！ ——实际上并不是一个非常英雄的人。作为一个故事装置，这很好。但仅靠自己创造一个引人入胜的故事是不够的。你必须让你的反英雄真正做一些有趣的事情，成为一个有趣的人，而不是只是坐在那里，非常引人注目，而不是成为命运的英雄。

我认识很多人，他们认为自己是命运英雄，但事实并非如此。他们没那么有趣。他们往往会陷入加密货币诈骗或花大量时间在网上大喊政治。

同样，雷伊在《最后的绝地武士》中并非贵族出身，这一点也不那么有趣。如果她从小就认为自己出身高贵，然后发现自己并非出身高贵，那可能会是一个非常酷的故事。事实上，这就是《普里登编年史》的情节，这是一部优秀的青少年奇幻系列，你们都应该读一读。但《最后的绝地武士》并没有这样做。雷伊并非贵族出身，这一事实对她来说实际上并不是情节的扭曲——这只是对那些习惯于期待不同事物的粉丝的扭曲。这本质上是一种无聊的事情。

许多特许经营权也非常努力地改变他们的风格和故事结构。一个很好的例子是《降世神通：最后的气宗》的续集《科拉传奇》。第一个系列是在一个很酷的原始世界中进行的非常简单的《命运英雄》任务。科拉试图摆脱这个公式，但从未真正找到其他有效的方法。每个季节基本上都是一个新的实验。第一季是与一些隐约左派革命者的战斗，第二季主要是展示魔法历史的闪回，第三季是与一些恐怖分子的战斗，第四季（最好的一季）是与法西斯征服者的战斗。 《科拉》值得一看，但没有任何一季能够真正重现《最后的气宗》的魔力。

《星际迷航：发现号》有点像这样。它摒弃了《星际迷航》通常的情节性质，转而采用长篇连续叙述。它将基调从乐观变为严峻和黑暗。它尝试了各种新的场景——平行宇宙、遥远的未来等等。所有这些都是有趣的实验，但没有一个真正赢得了《星际迷航》粉丝的喜爱。

这里的问题是，极力试图颠覆粉丝对特许经营权的喜爱，某种程度上违背了特许经营权的目的。电影和电视制片厂喜欢特许经营权，因为它们能吸引现有的已知观众。但如果你去掉了最初让观众喜欢该系列的风格，那么你还不如创建一个新的 IP。

这并不意味着球迷只是想要舒适的食物。许多特许经营权随着时间的推移而停滞不前，只是一遍又一遍地做同样的事情（漫威，我在看着你）。但最好随着时间的推移不断发展特许经营的主题和风格。不要把一个全新的东西放在观众面前，并期待他们热情地接受它，因为它的侧面画着特许经营标志，而是尝试将新元素逐一插入到熟悉的格式中，看看粉丝是否喜欢它。

《星际迷航》通过《下一代》做到了这一点，这是整个系列中最受欢迎和最成功的电视剧。第一季的开头与 60 年代的老剧非常相似，只是战斗少了一点，谈判多了一点。在接下来的两季中，TNG 演变成一种非常不同和原创的东西——一部几乎完全关于理解和同情未知事物的节目。同样，《星际迷航：深空九号》的成功是从 TNG 式的乐观主义慢慢演变为关于战争的黑暗故事。 TNG 和 DS9 的小规模、连续的实验取得了成功，而 Discovery 的大刀阔斧的改革却失败了。

另一个很好的例子是安道尔。最好的《星球大战》电视节目重点关注使原版电影变得伟大的政治主题和故事装置——对压倒性优势的反抗，选择无私而不是经济激励，等等。它以多种方式改变了原始格式，但并不试图彻底颠覆《星球大战》的一切。

所以这里的规则应该是：进化，而不是颠覆。当你在瓶子里抓住闪电时，不要放过它，并假设你可以再次抓住它，因为你的瓶子上有相同的标签。

最终，填充传说和颠覆主题都是捷径——在不弄清楚如何在现有的虚构宇宙中写出引人入胜的新故事的情况下继续特许经营的方法。尽管特许经营权的延续降低了讲故事的经济风险，但实际上并没有让它变得更容易。仅仅因为 IP 拥有固定的受众群体并不意味着该受众群体就很容易取悦。

改编、续集和翻拍的时代可能听起来很无聊、陈旧，但事实并非如此。

《经济学人》有一个关于中国科学崛起的好故事。就“高影响力”（即高引用率）出版物而言，中国已超越美国和欧洲：

现在，我们必须对这些数字持保留态度。通过查看有多少其他论文引用它们来衡量论文的影响力可能是对真实影响力的有偏见的衡量——你可能有一群研究人员互相大量引用，从而夸大了指标。 Qiu、Steinwender 和 Azoulay最近发表了一篇论文，他们认为这种现象在中国尤其普遍：

我们强调了与跨国比较特别相关的引文偏见的一个新来源：本土偏见，即研究人员过度引用本国研究人员的倾向……

我们发现，迄今为止，中国在所有国家中表现出最大的本土偏见。这并不是最近才出现的现象。尽管中国的本土偏见在过去二十年中一直在稳步增加，但在我们观察期开始的 2000 年，中国的引用已经出现了强烈的本土偏见。此外，中国的本土偏见并不是由任何特定的研究领域驱动的。相反，中国在 20 个广泛的科学领域中的 18 个领域表现出最强烈的本土偏见……

最后，我们发现本土偏见夸大了中国在科学领域的崛起。虽然中国在原始引用方面排名第二，仅次于美国，但一旦我们使用去偏见指标，它就会回落到第四位，落后于美国、英国和德国。如果人们认为家庭引用特别容易反映政治或战略考虑，而不是科学家基于他们选择引用的文章中所包含的想法而积累的认可，那么家庭去偏见引用计数可能会被视为特别有用。

研究人员基本上只是通过控制国家规模来识别“本土偏见”。他们对本土偏见的衡量仍然表现出某种明显的规模依赖性，欧洲小国处于规模的底部，而大国则位于顶部。所以我确实想知道他们是否正确控制了尺寸。但中国仍然绝对领先于包括印度在内的所有其他国家：

因此，虽然我认为作者关于英国在高影响力科学领域仍领先于中国的结论似乎很可疑，但就中国研究人员相互引用大量内容而言，这里似乎确实发生了一些事情。

您可以用几种不同的方式来解释这一点。 一种可能是，中国科学的质量比外国人想象的要高得多，而非汉语人士由于语言障碍而无法引用这些高质量的中国论文。另一种解释——Qiu 等人。建议——中国政府要求该国的研究人员出去撰写获得大量引用的论文，而研究人员基本上通过建立隐性或显性的引用环来回应。当然，这可能是这两种解释的某种组合。

（更新：在评论中，曾对作者署名膨胀进行研究并与中国科学家合作过的林志成提出了另一种解释。他认为，中国研究人员比其他地方的研究人员承受着更大的压力，需要引用自己部门内的高级研究人员.)

此外，尚不清楚中国在科学方面的支出是否超过发达国家。正如《经济学人》文章所示，自 20 世纪 90 年代以来，中国的研发支出快速增长：

但这部分是因为其经济增长迅速；中国用于研发的支出占 GDP 的百分比也在不断增加，但到目前为止，它只是向 2.5-3.5% 的全球标准靠拢：

（请注意，真正的研究支出大国是韩国，真正的落后者是法国。）

最重要的是，《经济学人》吹捧的国家研发支出数字实际上主要是企业的研发支出，而不是中国政府的研发支出：

这些研究大部分是在国有企业的企业实验室完成的，这些实验室早在1999年就接管了中国政府实验室的大部分研究职能。但中国大学的研发产出份额相当小，而且实际上已经萎缩了最近：

因此，中国在全球科学领域的主导地位，无论是在引用还是在支出方面，实际上并不像《经济学人》文章所描述的那样引人注目。

但在应用物理科学领域——尤其是在材料科学、化学和工程领域——中国无疑已经领先于西方，即使你接受邱等人的“偏见因素”。 （2024）：

医疗保健很棒，但中国在医疗支出上的吝啬正在伤害人民。但应用物理科学是美国希望培育的出口导向型高科技制造业（计算机芯片、电动汽车等）的关键投入。应用物理科学对于赢得战争也至关重要——对于制造大量高精度和破坏性导弹和其他武器等等。 《经济学人》当然认为军事实力是中国推动科学发展的一个重要因素：

中国共产党 (ccp) 将农业研究作为科学家的优先事项——它认为农业研究是确保国家粮食安全的关键……“工程学是现代中国的终极学科，”马金森教授说，“我认为这是部分与军事技术有关，部分是因为这是发展一个国家所需要的。”

因此，增强美国在物理科学领域的实力似乎是个好主意，不仅因为它可以改善世界并提高美国的国内生产总值，而且还可以帮助保持美国及其盟友的强大。

我们真的可以获得更多的联邦科学资助吗？

关于科学资助的讨论通常集中在联邦政府。部分原因是，当你想要改变某些事情时，政府资助是最容易拉动的政策杠杆。这也是因为政府资助是美国研究生态系统中的薄弱环节。随着时间的推移，美国私营部门的研发支出稳步上升，而政府对科学的资助占 GDP 的比例却在不断下降：

即使在大学内部，政府的作用在过去十年中也有所缩小：

因此，我们似乎应该做一件显而易见的事情，增加联邦对科学的资助。

但有一些理由对增加联邦资金作为灵丹妙药的解决方案持怀疑态度。首先，在美国现在可能进入的紧缩时代，联邦研发资金可能会受到影响。原因是研发资金在国会山没有太多天然的政治支持者——它的好处是分散的、长期的。

你可以在 2021-22 年看到这一情况的发生。 《CHIPS 和科学法案》最初是《无尽前沿法案》 ，这是增加政府研究经费的大胆愿景：

该法案由参议员查克·舒默(Chuck Schumer)和托德·杨(Todd Young)于去年首次提出，该法案将在国家科学基金会(NSF)内设立一个新的技术理事会，该理事会具有类似DARPA的项目结构，配备灵活的招聘和拨款权限。凭借五年内 1000 亿美元的预算，该局将有权使用赠款、合同、奖金以及与工业界、学术界和研究机构的合作协议来推动美国在十个广泛领域的创新前沿，其中包括尖端技术、人工智能和量子计算等技术，到机器人、制造、生物技术、先进能源技术和材料科学等更成熟但同样重要的领域。

这个想法部分基于 Jonathan Gruber 和 Simon Johnson 的著作，他们的优秀著作《Jump-Starting America》号召将联邦研发支出提高到 20 世纪 80 年代的水平（这是在约翰逊转向呼吁政府放慢进展之前）在人工智能领域）。布鲁金斯学会的研究人员以及保罗·罗默等增长经济学家也呼吁大力推动政府研发。

它从未发生过。国会大幅削减了该法案中的科学支出，并将其更名为《CHIPS 和科学法案》，以反映重点的转变。那里仍然有一些科学支出，但国会未能为此拨出大部分资金，有效地破坏了旧的无尽边境计划的其余部分：

两年后，国会为芯片制造商提供了全额补贴。然而，科学的巨大推动远远偏离了目标……国会已经削弱了该法律在基础研究和开发方面的雄心，旨在在人工智能等竞争领域保持领先于中国和其他竞争对手……

最新的例子是立法者在过去一周提出的支出方案：拜登的签名大幅削减了国家科学基金会的开支，并拖延了商务部和能源部本应部署 CHIPS 资金的关键办公室，从而使承诺的2000 亿美元现金注入变成了现实。十多年来一直经历着耻辱的发型……

“这些不是我想看到的数字。我很失望，我们无法提供与我们在 CHIPS 和 Science 中授权的资金相匹配的资金，”众议院科学主席 Frank Lucas（俄克拉荷马州共和党人）在一封电子邮件中告诉 POLITICO。 “不幸的是，在我们当前的财政环境下，我们必须做出艰难的决定，这反映在这些机构的预算中。”

重要的是要记住，当国会通过一项“花费”一定数额资金的法案时，该数额只是“授权”的——它实际上只是一个名义目标。这笔钱在稍后“拨款”之前并不确定是否会被花掉。所以基本上国会通过了一项法案，承诺在科学上投入大量资金，但后来却没有这样做：

由此可见，这是一场多么艰苦的战斗。

我们只需要直接的联邦资助吗？

然后是联邦直接资助与公司资助大学研究的激励措施的问题。从上图可以看出，联邦资助大学科学的比例一直在下降，现在刚刚超过 50%。但我们真正不知道的是，总的来说，这是好事还是坏事。

事实上，这是经济学界争论活跃的一个领域。例如， Fieldhouse 和 Mertens（2023）得出的结论是，政府资助的科学研究的经济回报确实很大。他们通过建立一个模型来做到这一点，在该模型中，政府研究创造“政府研发资本”，然后将其投入到整个经济中。将他们的模型与数据相匹配，他们发现政府非国防研发基本上促进了生产率的增长：

我们发现，对非国防研发拨款的积极冲击会强烈导致总 TFP 的延迟和逐步增长，在长期预测范围内（8 至 15 年），这种增长在统计上变得非常显着。对于导致政府研发资本增加 1% 的冲击，我们的基线估计显示 TFP 水平最终会增加约 0.2%。非国防研发的积极冲击也会导致各种创新活动指标的增加，例如专利授予量、STEM领域的博士获得者数量、从事研发的研究人员数量或技术出版物数量。

这是一个非常大的作用。作者发现对国防研发的影响要小得多，但认为这可能是因为研究结果出于军事目的而保密。

这是一个很酷的结果，但是这个分析的很多部分可能是错误的——基本模型依赖于一些理论假设，时间范围真的很长，无法识别任何东西，等等。还有一些其他论文似乎与某些结论相矛盾。例如， 巴比娜等人。 （2020）发现联邦资助的大学研究不太可能商业化：

[A] 联邦资金的份额增加会减少专利活动……[A] 联邦资金平均份额增加 10% 会使获得专利的可能性降低 0.4 个百分点，大约是平均值的一半。

作者还发现，更多的联邦资助往往会让研究人员留在学术界，尽管这也往往会增加他们创办初创企业的可能性。

与此同时，阿罗拉等人。 (2023)发现了与 Babina 等人类似的结果，并认为联邦研究经费往往会排挤私营部门的研究：

我们发现抽象的公共知识本身——科学期刊上的出版物——对企业研发的各个组成部分几乎没有影响。这意味着企业创新很大程度上对“纯粹”知识溢出没有反应。

其次，公共发明减少了企业研发。相关大学专利每增加一个标准差，企业专利就会减少约 51%，企业出版物会减少约 33%，AMWS 科学家的就业会减少约 8%。此外，我们发现公共发明的增加会降低公司的利润，这表明，总的来说，公共发明与企业发明的竞争大于它们作为企业创新投入的作用……[F]技术前沿的企业似乎对此反应较少公共发明与追随者相比……

综上所述，我们的发现表明，对公司创新至关重要的公共科学（科学发展为专利的发明并体现在人力的人力资本中）既是可排除在人力资本中）。因此，公共科学的扩展可能不会导致标准经济增长模型预测的持续生产率增长。

现在，您对这些发现的回应可能与以下方面相似：“谁在乎私营部门？谁在乎商业化？为此，谁在乎经济增长？科学的目的是发现宇宙的秘密并增加人类知识，而不是为某些股东而赚钱，而不是新自由主义者！”

但是，无论您对发现宇宙秘密的价值有何看法，如果研究支出永远不会进入创建新的商业化产品，则可能不太可能提高物质生活水平或加强国防。因此，如果我们想将科学用作丰富和加强国家的工具，我们应该担心结果表明联邦研究支出不是这样做的最佳方法。

因此，关于联邦研发资金是否是资助科学的最佳方法，有一些矛盾的结果。我认为一个安全的选择是将直接的联邦资金和与公司合作的激励措施混合在一起。

美国还能如何支持科学？

在我看来，最后的问题是，除了花更多的钱在研究上，美国是否还能做其他事情。我认为，尽管大学代表中国研究支出的份额稍小，但中国材料科学，化学和工程的迅速崛起还是有启发性的。

这并不意味着中国实验室的钱并不是这里的故事的一部分 - 事实并非如此。尽管公司实验室收获了更大的份额，但中国的大学也从中国快速经济增长中获得了一部分利益。但是，中国能够在不使学术界更重要的情况下统治应用的物理科学这一事实提出了一个问题，即美国是否能够完成类似的事情。

一种可能性是，中国实际上比美国更关注STEM教育，大约有41％的中国大学生在STEM中，而仅20％的美国人。但是，由于越来越多的美国人上大学，两国几乎拥有与人口的百分比相同的律师：

如果您将美国的数字乘以4.26（国家之间的人口比率），则您的数量与中国几乎完全相同。

这提出了一个问题：也许中国在研究中表现良好，因为它真的非常大？正如我们不能期望德国从长远来看平等的美国科学产出一样，也许是不现实的，希望美国与一个拥有四倍的国家的国家保持速度，这是不现实的。 （在此处插入明显的高技能移民的明显音调。）

换句话说，也许中国正沿着研发支出和STEM教育的方面成为一个普通的发达国家，但是由于它是如此巨大，它看起来好像做得更好。我发现这是西方人在看中国时犯的一个常见错误- 并不意识到它的表现超过了多少实际上只是大小的函数。

即使规模解释了中国的整体研发表现，也存在一个问题：中国正在研究的事情是否比美国和欧洲正在研究的事情更重要。美国和欧洲的研究对生命科学有更大的偏见，而中国研究对应用物理科学的偏见更加有偏见。因此，一个重要的问题是，美国及其盟友是否应该将支出从生物学转移到材料科学，工程和化学。

在美国，这可能涉及将资金从NIH（卫生与公共服务部的一部分）转移到更注重身体科学的机构，例如NSF和能源部。目前，NIH完全主导了非防御研究支出：

改变这种平衡可能是在应用物理科学中与中国竞争的关键。

无论如何，我认为有关中国科学统治的报道不应导致西方的决策者恐慌。但是，现在中国在应用物理科学研究中取得了领先的领先优势，西方领导人需要问自己是否真的有能力负担在这些领域的领导才能，这变得非常不可否认。

无论如何，让我们来获取2010年代的四个著名例子。

示例1：“世纪图表”

在1992年至2020年之间，美国的通货膨胀率通常很低，稳定。但是，总的通货膨胀率较低，掩盖了单个商品和服务价格的重大变化 - 有些事情变得更加昂贵，而其他情况则更便宜。马克·佩里（Mark Perry）和美国企业学院（American Enterprise Institute）的其他一些人在通常称为“世纪图表”的图表中说明了其中一些不同的价格变化。医疗保健，教育和儿童保育都变得更加昂贵，而汽车，衣物，家具，电子产品，手机服务和软件都变得更便宜。住房和食物在中间的某个地方。佩里（现在已退休）最近制作了图表的更新版本，将起点和端点移动一点，但图基本上看起来基本相同，所以我将使用此新版本：

这里的基本数据没有问题 - 它来自劳工统计局。 BLS并不总是能完美正确的一切 - 没人能做到 - 但是他们尽了最大的努力，而且他们有很多聪明的人不懈地工作，以使这些数据尽可能准确。

我确实有两个小问题在此图表显示数据的方式。首先，大学学费是标题编号，不包括经济援助。学生实际支付大学付费的价格比官方标签价格慢得多，并且在2006年之后没有上涨。其次，佩里选择的标签住房和红色标签，因为它们的上升速度比整体通货膨胀率略快，在这里有点怀疑 - 两者都比工资慢，因此它们在这段时间内变得更加负担得起，而不是较少。

但这是一个小问题。总体而言，这是一个很好的图表，具有良好的数据，它说明了近几十年来美国经济的一个清晰而重要的事实：物理商品通常越来越便宜，而服务通常越来越昂贵。

然而， 许多看到此图表的人认为，它揭示了服务价格的根本原因提高。他们认为这全都与政府的参与和监管有关：

等等。

这不是佩里的错。当他在2018年发布原始图表时，他建议这只是一种可能的解释：

看到任何模式吗？商品（像电视这样的进口竞争）与非交易（如育儿），制造商品（包括服装和汽车的进口竞争）与服务（医疗，医院，教育），竞争性（软件）与受保护的行业（医疗保健） ），政府参与/资金/法规的程度？

但是，“政府参与程度”的解释似乎比“可交易，不可交易”和“制造业与服务”的解释更为流行，尽管后者对许多趋势都是完全合理的解释。

实际上，当我们仔细观察此图表时，我们会看到“政府参与程度”叙述的许多差异。

大学教科书没有受到严格的监管，但其价格却大幅上涨 - 至少直到2010年代中期。教科书是通过廉价的学生贷款间接补贴的，但是在政府于2009 - 2012年从私营部门接管学生贷款市场之后不久，其价格实际上停止上涨。

手机服务受到高度监管，但其价格在图表中下降了。同时，住房可能是现有最受监管的行业，并且还通过税收减免和代金券通过政府补贴，但其价格在给定时间段的工资少于工资少于工资。

至于大学学费，私立学校的学费比公立学校要高得多，自90年代以来，他们的标价上涨了更多的美元。

实际上，由于法规和补贴的结合，服务很昂贵的流行观念并不能用作伞的解释。正如我去年在一篇文章中所写的那样，在某些情况下，补贴是故事的一部分，在某些情况下，法规是故事的一部分，但是这里有很多细微差别和异质性：

“政府参与”的故事也没有解释为什么在过去十年中，从90年代末到2010年代初的许多服务都变得越来越负担得起：

因此，尽管几乎可以肯定的是，政府参与在“世纪图表”的某些价格差异中发挥了作用，但这可能只是许多因素之一。像许多人一样，以图表为简单的“自由主义者是正确的”叙述是一个错误。

如果这里有一个总体课程，那就是当图表显示许多不同的趋势时，您应该期望这些趋势有几种不同的原因。很少有“一种经济理论来统治所有这些理论”，如果您认为图表已经证明了这种理论的存在，那么您很有可能会误解图表。

3.中国的关税可以帮助其余的发展中国家工业化

英国的专家- 甚至是一些美国专家- 继续违反拜登对中国产品的关税，同时完全忽略了关税背后的中心原理。搜索他们的耶利米德人，以示“军事”，“国防”和“国家安全”等词，这是一个完整的空白。因为他们甚至没有解决关税的最重要原因，所以他们对关税的争论不能被非常重视。

但最重要的是，关税批评家缺少了另一个重要的故事。关税为生产迁出中国提供了巨大的动力。但这并不意味着它将转移到美国 - 相反，它将转向印度，墨西哥，越南，印度尼西亚，菲律宾等发展中国家。发展经济学家Arvind Subramanian 写道：

关于美国与中国之间竞争不断升级的辩论通常缺少的是其他国家，尤其是更大的发展中经济体的观点。毕竟，这些关税不仅是贸易保护主义者，而且是歧视性的……oday的关税正受到从中国等对手的进口中的进口，将经济活动转移到了被认为是盟友的第三国供应商中……

印度提供了一个很好的例子。自2014年推出“中国加上一项”策略以来，它已经成功吸引了几家西方公司。尤其是，苹果大大扩展了其在印度的iPhone制造业务， 据报道，特斯拉可能会效仿……如果印度可以建立一个供应链，那么在很大程度上独立于中国 - 这种趋势在电子领域正在缓慢地发展 - 它可以比中国和与之相关的国家获得竞争优势……

他的战略利益与第三国的能力和比较优势之间的重叠程度更大，歧视性保护主义的可能性越大，对寻求从残酷有效的中国多样化的投资者提供了确定性。

Subramanian当然是对的，但是我认为他甚至还不够远！ Subramanian仅着眼于西方公司在中国以外的地区转移生产，因此他认为，越南和印度尼西亚等国家的供应连锁店与中国更加融合，将受益匪浅。但是，这忽略了这些国家将从中国公司远离中国的公司中受益的可能性。

目前，拜登的新关税仅在中国。这意味着，如果像Byd这样的中国公司在越南建立了工厂，他们可以按照目前所写的关税规避关税。最终，美国可能会堵塞看似漏洞的漏洞（尽管欧洲可能不会）。但是与此同时，中国公司在其他国家建立工厂有很大的动力。实际上，这正是他们在做的事情：

实际上，中国公司也在印度投资，尽管从长远来看，这将有助于印度成为中国的经济竞争对手。最后，个人激励措施通常会胜过民族主义的关注。

即使您忽略了该问题的国家安全方面，您也应该同意，将中国生产到印度，越南，印度尼西亚等的公司是一件非常好的事情。这些国家比中国要贫穷得多，这意味着它们比中国更需要增长：

最后，西方和中国公司都将工厂转移到新的发展中国家是旧的“飞根”发展理论的另一个实例。但是在这种情况下，鹅需要额外的推动力才能使他们离开中国。关税规定了这一推动力，因此全球穷人可能会受益匪浅。

4.租金控制有实际费用

在我的观察中，租房者和像Yimbys这样的人致力于使租房者的生活更轻松，被强烈吸引了租金控制的想法。毕竟，造成租房者立即痛苦的事情是……好吧，租金增加。因此，只要禁止痛苦的事情，可以让立即痛苦消失是可以理解的。

人们普遍认为，租金控制可能会对租房者产生负面的长期后果 - 该政策可能是临时的拐杖，使情况变得更糟。但是现在是现在，明天是明天，总是很想找到理由说服自己，短期福利无需成本。

但是现实是，长期成本通常在那里。 Konstantin Kholodilin对租金控制研究的研究有很大的新文献评论- 这是他所引用的所有研究的电子表格- 他得出结论，缺点是非常真实的：

租金控制是否有用，还是造成比公用事业更大的损害？…这项研究回顾了大型经验文献……在减慢为控制所支付的住宅的租金增长方面，租金控制似乎非常有效。但是，这项政策也导致了影响整个社会的广泛不利影响……

[a]通常在此研究的研究中，租金控制会导致不受控制的住所的租金更高。施加租金天花板会放大房屋的短缺。因此，等待的队列变得更长，将会成为租户，必须花更多的时间寻找住宅…

同样，租金控制对新的住宅建筑和供应的影响似乎是相似的。大约三分之二的研究表明了负面影响，而几项研究发现没有统计学上的显着影响……[v]租金控制政策的设计可能很重要……[n]可以免除构造的住房，因此仍然可以保持不受租金控制法规的影响…

关于租金控制对住房质量的影响，已发表的研究几乎是一致的。除Gilderbloom（1986）和Gilderbloom和Markham（1996）外，所有研究都表明，租金控制导致受法规约束的住宅质量的恶化。

因此，尽管租金控制为有幸生活在租金控制的单位中的人提供了很多好处，但它会导致整体住房库存较小且矮胖。这会伤害那些不在租金控制的单位中的人，无论是通过提高租金和使他们难以找到搬家的地方而难以通过。

这并不意味着租金控制永远不值得。但这意味着有一个价格，主张租金控制的人需要考虑一下。

5.这些天的服务成本增加了较慢

还记得那些显示诸如医疗保健和教育之类的服务的图表在美国的负担得起吗？

这通常是一个非常好的图表。这不是一个完美的图表 - 它夸大了大学的成本，因为它忽略了经济援助，并且其数据源可能低估了 最近的学费下降。另外，它使住房陷入了红色，因为即使工资上涨了更多的价格，住房的价格上涨了。但是这些是较小的问题 - 总的来说，图表准确地传达了一个事实，即自本世纪之交以来，大型服务的价格降低了，即使许多物理商品变得更加负担得起。

但是，当您这样的“增加百分比增加”图表时，您选择的开始年很重要。如果您改变了开始的一年，趋势通常看起来会大不相同。正如杰里米·霍雷德（Jeremy Horpedahl）指出的那样，自2000年以来，自2013年以来的许多大型服务实际上变得更加负担得起：

医院服务在这里是一个很大的离群值，但是医疗服务总体上变得更加负担得起，大学，日托和住房也是如此。这真是个好消息。它充满了希望，几十年来的大量服务成本增加是一种一次性现象，不会重复。

当然，这并没有改变我们应该寻找使医疗保健，教育和住房更负担得起的方法的事实。但这意味着逆风阻止我们无法做到这一点，现在可能已经放松了。这是一个重要的提醒，即经济趋势并没有设定为石头。

现在写这篇文章几乎有点毫无意义。拜登政府在选举日之前将无法在中国阵线上做更多的事情，如果特朗普获胜，就中国政策而言，所有赌注几乎都会失败。但是我认为将这些想法推向一般讨论是一件好事。

美国经济政策的转变与中国有关，这一切都与国防竞争有关。正如Greg IP所写的那样，新范式有三个部分 - 工业政策，出口控制和关税。关税可以保护军事上有用的美国行业免受中国出口的突然浪潮的破坏，工业政策构成了美国军事有用的行业，出口管制减慢了中国对军事有用行业的发展。这些政策也有其他好处 - 脱碳，创造就业，技术进步等 - 但最终是中国与发达民主国家之间的防御平衡，从根本上讲是在这里驱动了一切的一切。

随着一般框架的发展，拜登政府的三个支柱还不错。工业政策尚未得到证明，如果滥用滥用，关税很容易适得其反，并且出口控制仍然包含许多漏洞。但总的来说，这是一种合理的方法。

不过，这还不够。在新的政策方法中，至少可以识别出至少剩余的三个漏洞非常容易。正如IP所写的那样，“第四回合，与盟友的统一经济阵线，仍然没有实现。”同时，如果最终产品在中国以外组装，关税不容易针对中国组件。尽管芯片和电池行业的工业政策很重要，但美国仍在忽略无人机。

阻止中国“遗产”芯片为一切供电

美国对中国的出口控制旨在防止中国主导制造先进的尖端半导体。几乎没有希望停止中国在芯片制造中的进步，但希望是放慢他们的进步，以至于美国及其盟友可以保持领先地位。这就是为什么出口控制和其他一些限制的原因是考虑到“ 小院子，高栅栏”的方法。

但是大量的计算机芯片不是前沿的。 They are “legacy”, “trailing-edge”, or “foundational” chips (three terms that mean the same thing). They are older tech that's much simpler to make — China already knows how to make them, and has the tools to make them in large numbers. Export controls have little or no hope of impeding China's progress in making legacy chips.

But just because legacy chips are technologically less sophisticated doesn't make them less important. As the Rhodium Group notes , these chips power most of the things in our economy:

Legacy chips are pervasive and therefore essential. Virtually every electronic device—including cars, airplanes and fighter jets, medical devices, smartphones, computers, and agricultural and industrial equipment—is powered by mature node chips in conjunction with leading-edge processors. Pandemic-related restrictions drove home how the absence of a single chip could hold up entire manufacturing assembly lines, leaving consumers in disbelief that their new cars could be stripped of features normally taken for granted, like seats that heat up and adjust automatically.

Currently, a majority of these chips are still made outside China, but China is racing to catch up, building absolutely enormous amounts of new fabs:

Much of this new capacity will be used in China, to make products for Chinese consumers. But much of it will be exported — either directly, or embedded in other Chinese-made products such as cars and electronics. As we've seen with autos and batteries, once China revs up its industrial machine and starts showering an industry with subsidies, it can be very hard for companies in other advanced countries to survive in the face of the onslaught. And legacy chips are one of China's most heavily subsidized industries.

There are several ways this could hurt the US and its allies.

First, competition from China's legacy chip industry could swamp and destroy much of the chip industries of the US and its allies — Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Europe, as well as the nascent chip industry in India. This would put supply chains in danger in the event of a war.

It would also deprive chipmakers outside China of the revenues to fund development in leading-edge chips, leaving them more dependent on government subsidies. Destroying the legacy chip businesses of companies like TSMC, Intel, and Samsung could be China's answer to export controls.

And finally, there's the cybersecurity angle. Some people fear that Chinese-made legacy chips could come with built-in backdoors that would allow China's military to spy on Americans, disable US infrastructure, turn a bunch of US equipment and consumer products into bricks, or even take control of vehicles and crash他们。

So there are plenty of reasons to try to prevent China from being the country that makes legacy chips for everyone else. But how to do that? The Rhodium Group suggests various types of trade barriers , including tariffs, to keep Chinese chips out of the US supply chain. And Chinese chips were included in Biden's recent round of tariffs .

But you can't put a tariff on something you don't even see coming into the country. Currently, the US government has very little idea where the chips in its imports come from. If a car from Mexico or a laptop made in Thailand has a Chinese chip somewhere in it, the US government simply doesn't know about it. This means that although it's pretty easy to block imports of Chinese chips themselves, it's very hard to block imports of products that contain Chinese chips.

The first task, then, is to get good data on where all the chips in US imports come from. Right now, data on component imports only comes out from the OECD with a lag of several years , and even that does not provide a product-by-product and company-by-company breakdown. The US needs to implement a reporting and inspection regime that gives the government good, up-to-the-minute information on where every computer chip in the country was physically made, which company owned the factory that made it, and which company designed it 。

Data is clearly the most important thing here. But there are also some other policy steps we could take, as outlined in a recent Noahpinion guest post by Steven Glinert. These include A) export restrictions on software used to design legacy chips, and B) more CHIPS Act money or similar subsidies for legacy chipmakers. Both of these would probably have only a marginal effect, but they could be a complement to trade barriers.

Really, though, data is the key thing here. You can't fight what you can't see, and currently, the US government can't see Chinese chips at all. I don't know of any current or planned government effort to identify Chinese chips in US imports.

Build a civilian drone industry

US industrial policy, export controls, and tariffs are aimed at strategic industries — chips, autos, batteries, and so on. But there's a hugely important industry that seems to have left out of this effort so far: drones.

By now, many, many writers have pointed out that drones have become essential to modern warfare. In Ukraine, vast numbers of drones are used for reconnaissance, artillery targeting, destroying enemy vehicles, and even killing enemy personnel directly. If you can stomach it, I recommend watching a small toy drone armed with a simple explosive chase down and kill a Russian soldier on the battlefields of Ukraine. That drone was piloted remotely by a human, but in the not-so-distant future, drones will be autonomous AI-powered killing machines . At that point, it's an open question of whether human soldiers will even be able to survive on the front lines of war.

Basically, there are two ways to power a drone: internal combustion engines, and electric motors. Drones powered by internal combustion tend to be larger, heavier, faster, and more powerful. But electric drones tend to be much cheaper and can be manufactured in higher volumes. A Shahed drone, one of the smallest and cheapest internal combustion drones, costs somewhere between $20,000 and $375,000 apiece. In contrast, a DJI Mavic 3 costs around $2,000 , while a larger Matrice 300 costs around $13,000 . Both types of drones have their uses on the battlefield, meaning any country that can't build or easily procure cheap electric-powered drones in large numbers is now at a disadvantage in war.

Chinese companies currently have an overwhelmingly high market share in the manufacture of commercial electric drones, with DJI as the dominant player. The second-biggest company is the US' Skydio, but they're still far behind DJI, and there are no other big US drone-makers. This means that modern battlefields like Ukraine are being dominated by Chinese-made products. And it means that if China ever goes to war with the US and its allies, the latter will find themselves without a lot of small electric-powered drones.

The US has considered banning Chinese drones, but as far as I know, no one is talking about an industrial policy to build up the US' own drone industry. The Biden administration seems to be thinking about drones as analogous to missiles or artillery shells — a form of ammunition rather than a type of vehicle, and therefore something that only the military needs to buy. But in a protracted war with China, a civilian US drone industry would provide important surge capacity for the US Military, much like automakers made tanks and airplanes during WW2.

One possible industrial policy to encourage the creation of a US commercial drone industry would be deregulation . The FAA has already loosened regulations on small commercial drones considerably, but allowing drones to be operated beyond visual line of sight (BVLOS) would help considerably, since this is how drones are used in wars. BVLOS deregulation is now in the works in Congress, but it's not yet clear how meaningful the changes will be.

But although you can encourage drone consumption with deregulation, in the end you're limited by how many consumers actually want to buy drones. With electric cars and computer chips, this was less of a problem, but drones are kind of a niche market, even in China. Usually, manufacturers need a big consumer market in order to scale up and drive down costs. So how did Chinese companies get so good at making drones?

Glenn Luk had a great post about this back in 2018, where he pointed out that most of the things that are used to make a drone are also used to make a phone . The big exception is the electric motor itself, which is more similar to the motor in a blender or other household appliance.

So a US industrial policy for drones would simply entail incentives for manufacturing drone components — electric motors, displays, cameras, etc. — in the US or select allied countries. This would be similar to the way the Inflation Reduction Act incentivizes domestic manufacturing of batteries, rather than the way the IRA incentivizes the manufacturing of EVs themselves. The final demand for the consumer products that these components would go into — phones, electric appliances, and so on — would already be there (and in fact, some of that demand is already subsidized by the IRA).

This industrial policy wouldn't cost nearly as much as the IRA or the CHIPS Act, since electronics components other than chips and batteries are pretty cheap. But it could help resuscitate a domestic consumer electronics industry that could be quickly repurposed as a drone industry if needed. So although no one seems to be talking about subsidizing the electric motor industry or the display industry, it seems like a useful hole to plug.

A united front

It's important to remember how much bigger China is than the US It has four times the population and twice the manufacturing capacity by value-added. Any protracted conflict between the two countries would see the US badly outmatched, despite its modest remaining advantages in some areas of technology. In other words, US national security relies crucially on alliances — in order to be able to stand up to a much bigger opponent, you need a gang.

While the US is pretty good at military alliances, it's not as good at economic alliances. To be fair, no one really is — economic relationships are much more multifaceted than defense cooperation, so there's no standard template for exactly how they're supposed to work. But there are a few areas where the US could cooperate more closely with allies in the quest to build a multinational economy capable of matching China's.

The most obvious area is export controls . The US needs countries like the Netherlands, Japan, Germany, South Korea, and Taiwan to cooperate if it's to have any chance of keeping cutting-edge chipmaking technology out of China's hands. So far, the Biden administration has done a pretty good job of this.

Second, the US should immediately pursue defense manufacturing collaboration among all its allies. The US' withered defense-industrial base and lack of a commercial shipbuilding industry means will take time to fix; in the meantime, America should be relying heavily on partners like Japan and South Korea to make the military materiel needed to deter China. Fortunately, there are already some moves in this direction :

The US and its allies in the Indo-Pacific are moving toward establishing a de facto "common market" for the defense industry, setting the same industrial standards and reinforcing each other's defense industrial base…The recent loosening of export controls among AUKUS partners…for building nuclear-powered submarines has created an opening for more region-wide defense-industry collaboration among allies, economist and defense analyst William Schneider said…

Schneider said that Japan in particular was ripe for such defense collaboration at the industry level, citing the country's substantial shipbuilding capacity.

Undersecretary William LaPlante, the Pentagon's top official for acquisition and sustainment, will start meeting with Japanese counterparts…to discuss collaboration. He will convene in Tokyo the inaugural meeting of the US-Japan Defense Industrial Cooperation, Acquisition, and Sustainment Forum, inviting representatives from American and Japanese defense contractors to discuss joint development, production and maintenance of weaponry…

"One of the things that Undersecretary LaPlante is promoting is the concept of an alliance industrial base," Schneider said.

A second area, which the US has done much less on, is trade . I wrote about this a couple months ago:

China's strategic companies — Huawei, BYD, and the rest — have access to one gigantic market. By some measures , that market is even bigger than that of the US But the US, Europe, Japan, Korea, etc. would be an even bigger combined market. Unifying those markets would give American and allied companies — Intel, Boeing, Samsung, Toyota, Airbus, Tesla, Hyundai, and so on — the ability to scale more and to drive down costs. If India were added, the bloc would be even bigger and more powerful.

So to the degree that the US can forge its alliances into a unified trading bloc , it should. The challenge, however, is that most other countries are not as willing to cut China out of their supply chains. Forging an anti-China economic bloc is kind of useless if the other members of that block are just acting as conduits for Chinese goods. The Biden administration has made some efforts to get other countries to come along on Biden's tariffs, but these efforts will inevitably be very sparse and of dubious effectiveness.

One idea here would be to reward strategically important companies in allied countries with access to the US market in exchange for harmonizing their China trade policies with America's. Those companies would effectively be offered a choice — do business with the US or do business with China. Meanwhile, the US could ask allies to offer similar deals to its own companies in strategic industries.

Alternatively, if the US can manage to get good data on component sourcing throughout the supply chain, it could just enact free trade agreements with all its allies and then tax Chinese components. But this would require both A) much better data collection on imported components, and B) the American public agreeing to something called a “trade deal”. In the wake of the bipartisan crusade to sink the TPP, prospects for the latter look dim. So the real trick here is to get the benefits of a trading alliance without triggering a protectionist backlash.

In general, though, I think more rhetoric about economic alliances, and the differences between trading with allies and trading with enemies, would help prepare the American public for all of the policies listed above. The US facing a rival bigger and more powerful than any we've ever faced, and there's just no way we can go it alone. That's a message I don't expect Trump or his followers to be receptive to, which is why Democrats need to stand up and lead here.

In 2022, I wrote a post arguing that batteries would be the defining technology of the 2020s. That was just a few months before the release of ChatGPT and the boom in generative AI. In light of that sudden efflorescence, the humble battery might seem quaint and prosaic, and my post might seem laughably mistimed.

And yet two years later, I think my post still holds up. These two years have seen small battery-powered drones utterly change the way wars are fought . They have seen battery storage become a common complement to solar, solving almost all of solar's intermittency problem and drawing huge amounts of investment worldwide. Batteries have powered the sudden meteoric rise of China's car industry , which went from an also-ran to a juggernaut that suddenly threatens to dominate the entire global auto market. AI is certainly magical and holds incredible potential, but in just a couple of years, batteries have begun to transform human energy supply, war, transportation, and geopolitical dominance.

Also, it's quickly becoming apparent that AI and batteries are, in many ways, perfectly complementary technologies. Drones are human-piloted now, but autonomous AI-operated drone swarms are coming, and they are going to change war and the balance of power yet again. AI promises to turn robotics from a niche type of machine tool into a ubiquitous feature of our world . The rise of autonomous machines will be — must be — battery-powered.

So here's my post from 2022. See how well you think it still holds up.

In 2015, Benedict Evans wrote a very influential piece called “ The smartphone is the new sun ”. By the middle of the 2010s, it was pretty clear that that decade would be defined in many ways by the mobile computing platform that Steve Jobs unveiled in 2007. For regular people, smartphones became the locus of their lives — an ever-present tether constantly connecting them to the digital world and allowing them to navigate the physical one. For industry, smartphones and the applications they enabled became a massive opportunity for investment and profit.

Now, however, it seems like we might be reaching the end of that rainbow. The basic reason is that with smartphones, IT companies have now harvested essentially all of people's surplus attention and time. A new Pew survey of teens' social media habits found that almost half of young people are online “almost constantly”, up from a quarter in the mid-2010s. And smartphone penetration in rich countries is around 80%. So it's natural for both consumers and investors/entrepreneurs to be looking around for what technologies might enable another Cambrian explosion of innovation in the next decade.

Many people think that this technology is going to be machine learning/AI. But although I do think ML will indeed be very important, I'm going to make an argument that the general-purpose technology that will really transform our society is the battery.

This is interesting because it's a bit of a swerve from the pattern of the last four decades. From 1980-2020, the innovations that reshaped our world were all in information technology — the PC, the internet, the smartphone and the social network. But batteries are an “atoms” technology — something that powers our physical world instead of helping us spin a new digital one. So the Decade of the Battery will look more like earlier decades, in which physical appliances like washing machines, refrigerators, and air conditioning were the hot new thing .

In fact, we can already see the shift in the 2010s — after all, batteries are what enabled smartphones.

The fundamental reason that batteries are becoming so important is simply that the technology has improved by leaps and bounds. Although batteries are improving on practically any metric , the two clearest indicators are cost and energy density. The cost of batteries, measured in dollars per kWh stored, has fallen by a factor of 42 since 1991 and by a factor of 2.5 since 2010:

Meanwhile, energy density more than tripled between 1990 and 2010:

The lion's share of this improvement was due to R&D efforts , but industrial scaling effects are starting to have a significant impact as well.

But of course that still leaves the basic question of what batteries will be used for . I'm going to go through a bunch of use cases, from the obvious (cars and energy storage) to the not-so-obvious. But first, I should talk a bit about why batteries are such a general-purpose technology.

Batteries solve two fundamental problems at once

Energy is obviously fundamental to every piece of industrial society, and it's especially important for physical (“atoms”) technologies like transportation, manufacturing, electricity, and appliances. We often think in terms of primary energy — that is to say, where we get the energy from. Technologies like solar and wind and nuclear and hydropower supply this need, and of course burning fossil fuels does this too. Batteries don't do this.

But there's more to energy than generation. We also have to store the energy, and we have to transport it from place to place. In other words, we have to move energy around through both time and space, so that we can use it wherever and whenever we want. Batteries address both problems.

When it comes to storage, batteries are not yet as good as fossil fuels, because they leak energy over time. This is why they can be used for short-term energy storage for power plants and grids, but not for seasonal storage. But for transporting energy, there are some ways in which batteries are qualitatively superior to fossil fuels. First of all, a battery can be charged by basically any electrical power source, whereas an oil pipeline or a natural gas tank can only really hold one specific type of fossil fuel. Second, extracting energy from a battery is generally much less noisy than extracting energy using a combustion engine. There are other advantages too.

Most importantly, though, a battery doesn't require a bulky combustion engine in order to extract the energy. I first realized the importance of this when I read about Portland protesters in the summer of 2020 using battery-powered leaf blowers to blow tear gas back in the face of federal agents. Battery-powered leaf blowers are less powerful than gasoline-powered ones, but they're also much lighter . This is why we use batteries for small, lightweight drones. It's a big part of the reason why your smartphone has a battery in it instead of a little gasoline-powered engine.

Any time some battery skeptic tells you that batteries have “lower energy density” than fossil fuels, point this out to them.

And as batteries continue to improve, their disadvantages compared to fossil fuels will decrease. We will develop batteries with longer life spans, greater power density, and so on.

The obvious use cases — cars and power storage

So, on to a big list of things we'll use batteries for. The two most obvious cases are electric cars and electric power storage for power plants and buildings. Everyone knows by now about the EV revolution — there are Teslas driving all over our city streets. And everyone knows about solar and wind energy, and how these are intermittent and need storage in order to keep powering our buildings at night and during storms. David Roberts has a great post about this , and he notes that transportation is really the bulk of the market here:

The EV market is going absolutely vertical, while global sales of internal combustion vehicles have flattened out and are forecast to decline relentlessly. We appear to be in the midst of a rapid shift to electric cars.

Utility scale or building scale energy storage won't really change our daily lives — in fact, the general idea is to prevent our daily lives from having to change as we replace fossil fuels with renewables. Electric cars, though, will definitely make the world feel different.

First of all, since electric cars charge at night, it means you'll only very rarely have to fill up your car, instead of having to go to the gas station every time your tank is empty. As electric cars get better range — and they're very close to gasoline cars now — this will mean that people will almost never have to stop to fill up, because their car will always start out fully charged in the morning. A big time-waster — looking for a gas station, sitting around huffing toxic fumes while your tank fills up — will mostly just vanish. It will also be a lot easier for autonomous vehicles to self-charge than to pump their own gasoline, once we get those.

Second, electric cars are much much quieter than gasoline cars — so quiet that we have to actually add noise just to prevent kids from getting run over in the street! And electric trucks will make living near highways and big thoroughfares much less onerous.

Finally, electric cars just make driving a better experience. They're much more responsive than gasoline cars, and they're also considerably cheaper to fill up. People who want to switch to transit-centric development won't like this , but people who don't have the option of riding the train will be happy.

So the well-known use cases for batteries are getting really big already. But in addition, there are a lot of less obvious but still transformative battery-dependent technologies that are growing fast as well.

Don't sleep on e-bikes

Everyone talks about electric cars. A few people talk about electric scooters. Very few people talk about e-bikes. But more electric bicycles are now sold than electric cars in the US:

E-bikes are already a $40 billion business globally , and growing fast.

E-bikes aren't like normal bikes — they add electric power to your muscle power to produce a much easier ride. That transforms cycling in two ways. First, it allows you to go much farther. From a recent study in Norway:

The people who bought e-bikes increased their bicycle use from 2.1 kilometers (1.3 miles) to 9.2 kilometers (5.7 miles) on average per day; a 340% increase. The e-bike's share of all their transportation increased dramatically too; from 17% to 49%, where they e-biked instead of walking, taking public transit, and driving….[I]n fact, people rode their e-bikes more the longer they had them[.]

Second, e-bikes make it pretty easy to bike uphill . That opens up huge areas to cyclists that were basically denied to them before (eg most of San Francisco).

The combination of much longer range and not having to worry about road grades mean that e-bikes have the potential to transform the way we live. Since the US already has roads and can add bike lanes where they don't already exist, the cost of converting cities to accommodate masses of e-bike commuters will not be large (certainly smaller than, say, building trains!). And since e-bikes are small and easy to park, we can build a lot of bike racks close to common destinations, taking away some of the hassle of finding a parking space when commuting.

All in all, e-bikes will simply make it much easier to get around our cities, which hopefully will increase human connection and make us feel more free. They will also make food and product delivery a lot easier in many areas. And because e-bikes do still use a little muscle power, we might become a bit healthier too!

It's also worth noting that electric cargo ships and planes are in the pipeline, though I don't expect these to become common in the next decade.

Drones are the future of warfare

Batteries aren't just going to change civilian transportation — they're going to change military vehicles as well, enabling whole new ways of warfare. Anyone who is paying attention to the war in Ukraine already knows this. Although combustion-powered drones like the Bayraktar get most of the attention, little electric drones have started delivering precision strikes at relatively close range on the battlefield. And this isn't just because Ukraine has less money and is forced to resort to cheap crappy weapons; the Russians are using battery-powered drones as well. And of course these drones are also extremely useful for battlefield reconnaissance, which is crucial for targeting modern precision weapons.

The advent of cheap reliable energy-dense batteries makes this possible. Battery-powered drones are small, cheap, and relatively quiet. And in the era of increased geopolitical competition and conflict, innovation in military drones is probably just getting started. Anti-personnel drones to clear soldiers out of dense urban areas with minimal damage to the surrounding structures are probably on the way. Autonomous swarming drones are being developed too. And battery-powered robots may help carry equipment across the battlefield , or even carry and fire weapons previously reserved for infantry.

In the extreme scenario, humans could be driven from the battlefield completely. Batteries, with their small size, light weight, and cheap price, will probably be crucial to that.

Battery-powered everything

EVs, ebikes, and drones only scratch the surface of the transformation of our physical world that light, small, cheap energy portability provides.

First, consider appliances. Cordless equipment will gradually take over from stuff that needs to be plugged in all the time. Battery-powered air purifiers and fans and humidifiers will stand around our houses and buildings. Battery-powered kettles and crock pots and pressure cookers and other cooking appliances will let us cook food in the park. Cordless vacuums, leaf-blowers, and mowers will make it much easier to keep our houses and lawns neat and tidy. Battery-powered webcams will allow us to more easily capture much of the world on video.等等。 Just look at everything that has a cord in your house, and ask if you might want to run it far from an outlet. Batteries let you do that.

Some special kinds of batteries also have other capabilities that allow them to be used in everyday applications that most people wouldn't think of. A really cool example is fast-discharging batteries that can be used to make super-powerful appliances .

Next, think about robots. Currently we have battery-powered roombas vacuuming our houses. Little delivery robots are starting to trundle down the street . Robot waiters are starting to appear in restaurants . And robots are going to be used in all kinds of industrial applications, from transporting parts and tools around factory floors to cleaning off solar panels . Battery-powered farm vehicles are beginning to transform agriculture .

In fact, although I said I didn't think machine learning was going to be the #1 most transformative tech of the 2020s, it's obviously the case that AI and batteries go together like peanut butter and jelly. As battery-powered drones and robots proliferate and fill our physical world, AI will be crucial for making sure it all runs correctly. So just as the smartphone revolution was powered by batteries, the battery revolution will be powered by AI.

Basically, the battery revolution means that the pieces of our world are starting to free themselves, get up, and move around.

Venture capitalists and technology companies, of course, stand to profit handsomely off of all this. “Deep tech” is a hot buzzword in the VC industry right now, but the big challenge is that many forms of deep tech — biopharma and other research-intensive industries — is that the long lead time and high up-front cost presents big challenges for the traditional low-cost, fast-scaling VC financing model. Battery-driven tech, however, may prove an exception. The fact that the basic research is being done in universities frees up VCs to fund applications instead of labs. And the fact that energy portability allows gadgets to adapt themselves to existing infrastructure means that investors won't have to tussle so much with regulators or fund expensive modifications to the built environment.

There are, of course, some big obstacles for us to overcome in the Decade of the Battery. Chief among these is mineral availability. Putting batteries in everything requires mining a whole bunch of lithium, copper, cobalt, and other minerals (David Roberts, as usual, has an excellent rundown ). This will require us to do a lot of mining, to shift toward types of batteries that aren't as dependent on rare minerals, and to diversify our sources away from unfriendly regimes. It's a challenge, but probably a doable one . And of course recycling and disposal of batteries will be a major task as well.

But no technological revolution has been without its challenges and its issues. The upside of batteries — a technology for cheap light energy portability and storage — just swamps the difficulties and downsides. It took a long time for this general-purpose technology to arrive, but now it's here, and the next decade (or, really three decades) will see it transform the world around us.

Donald Trump still leads in most polls, and betting markets give him a better than even chance of winning the election this November. So it's important to think about what his actual policies would be, and how these would affect the outcomes that Americans care about. Right now, the outcome Americans probably care about most is inflation. So we should get ahead of the game here, and think about how Trump's policies would affect prices.

This is an inherently difficult exercise. Trump isn't wedded to a particular ideology, and is often very open to persuasion — especially if you come bearing large checks for him and his businesses. Predicting whether he'll follow through on his policy promises in a forceful and substantive way, or whether he'll make a symbolic gesture and leave it at that, is always tough. But if we're going to make an informed decision about who should be President, we need to take our best guess.

The basic story here is that there are three main ways Trump could increase inflation in the US: tariffs, deficits, and pressuring the Fed to lower interest rates.

Tariffs and inflation

A number of people are warning that Trump will raise inflation by putting up high tariffs. For example, here's Matt Yglesias :

[T]ariffs have a distinct inflationary impact…[Consider] a 10 percent tax on imported olive oil. That makes imported olive oil more expensive…But it's also going to raise the price of domestic olive oil, because price competition from foreigners has diminished…[N]ow imagine doing this across the economy. The price of everything goes up.

Trump has promised a 10% tariff on all imports from all countries, a 60% tariff on all Chinese goods, and a 200% tariff on all cars made by Chinese-owned companies. Tariffs raise consumer prices — in economics terms, they represent a negative supply shock . Negative supply shocks reduce growth, increase unemployment, and push up inflation. So if you care about inflation, it's reasonable to worry about this.

There are lots of uncertainties concerning just how much tariffs push up prices. To give just one example: Without action to reduce the dollar's role as the world's reserve currency, it's likely that tariffs would result in the dollar getting stronger, which would allow Americans to buy imported goods more cheaply and would thus cancel out some of the effects of the tariff. It seems unlikely to me that Trump would take the dramatic, wrenching actions needed to devalue the dollar, so currency appreciation is one force in the economy that would “push back” against the effects of tariffs. (Of course if Trump did actually go ahead and devalue the dollar, that would produce even higher inflation .)

In fact, dollar appreciation in 2018 might be one reason why Trump's tariffs in his first term didn't push up consumer prices much for Americans — only by 0.2% total , according to one study.

Because of these uncertainties, different models arrive at different conclusions for how much Trump's proposed tariffs would increase inflation. For example, Bloomberg's economics team forecasts a total increase of 2.5% in consumer prices from all of Trump's proposed tariffs, while Robinson and Thierfelder (2022) predict an increase of 6.7% from just the 10% global tariff alone.

This would be a one-time price increase, not a long-term rise in the inflation rate. But as we saw in 2021-22, even a temporary burst of inflation can make voters very unhappy for a while, and a 6.7% increase in consumer prices is nothing to sneeze at.

So the danger of tariff-driven inflation is real, but the effect would be transitory, and there's a real possibility that it would be modest in size. Other potential Trump policies, however, could have bigger and longer-lasting effects.

Deficits and inflation

We tend not to associate Trump with inflation, because it was low in his first term. But that doesn't mean his policies didn't contribute to the inflation of 2021-22. The $2.2 trillion CARES Act and its $0.9 trillion follow-up in December 2020 handed out massive amounts of money to American households — even more than Joe Biden handed out in 2021. Americans initially saved most of that money instead of spending it, but in 2021 they started spending that saved-up cash. Most macroeconomists think that this spending binge contributed significantly to inflation in 2021 and early 2022.

Now, I supported those bills! In my opinion, Trump did the right thing here , because making sure that Americans weren't financially ruined by Covid, and that the US economy recovered quickly, were more important than keeping inflation low. But the impact of Trump's pandemic spending does demonstrate two things:

  1. Fiscal spending can contribute significantly to demand-side inflation

  2. Trump doesn't have much of an instinct for austerity

In fact, Trump's distaste for austerity and lack of concern about deficits predates the pandemic. Thanks largely to Trump's tax cuts, the federal deficit increased from 3.4% in 2017 to 4.6% of GDP in 2019. And austerity in general is not the kind of thing populist leaders do — they tend to hand out short-term goodies to keep themselves popular, even if this leads to greater pain for the citizenry in the long term.

So what would Trump's deficit policies look like in a second term? In his post, Yglesias flags an analysis by the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, which shows how extending the tax cuts from Trump's first term would increase the national debt:

Now, that's not a huge increase, and the blue line for “current law” shows that Biden is already doing quite a lot of deficit spending. But it's likely that Biden's deficits are already contributing to stubbornly above-target inflation. As I wrote in a post back in April , macroeconomics theory tends to think that government budget deficits are inflationary:

It's theoretically possible that deficits can be inflationary. In fact, this is how a typical New Keynesian macro model works . It's also implied by a theory called the Fiscal Theory of the Price Level . So it might be the case that the US government's big deficits might be causing inflation to remain stubbornly above target.

Now as I noted in that post, macroeconomic theory isn't always a great guide to reality. There are situations where governments have run up huge debts without sparking inflation — for example, Japan. But it's certainly worth worrying that higher deficits under Trump would push up inflation.

And this problem is getting worse, because of rising interest costs. As the US government rolls over more and more of its low-interest legacy debt from before the pandemic at the new, higher interest rates, it has to pay more and more each month just to service the debt. That is causing deficits to rise — we're borrowing to fund the interest on our own borrowing.

Austerity is the only way to deal with that problem. Whether Biden and Congress are willing to engage in austerity after this election is an open question, but Trump's record — and his general populist approach to governing — suggest he won't be willing to deal with the problem.

Instead, I expect Trump to try to deal with rising interest costs a different way — by pressuring the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates.

Monetary interference and inflation

In theory, the Fed is supposed to be independent — it's supposed to manage interest rates in order to strike a balance between high employment and low inflation. This means that when inflation rises, the Fed is supposed to do the dirty, thankless job of raising interest rates to fight it. Raising interest rates can cause a lot of short-term economic pain — for example, when Paul Volcker raised rates in the early 1980s, bringing inflation down at the cost of two painful but short-lived recessions. In other words, it's the Fed's job to be “bad cop” in the economy, and we give it a degree of autonomy in order to insulate it from the inevitable political backlash when hard choices are needed.

During his first term in office, Donald Trump repeatedly attacked the Fed, demanding that the Fed cut interest rates even more from their already low levels. This made many people feel that Trump was trying to compromise the Fed's independence — applying political pressure on them for his own short-term political benefit.

Now, Trump's allies are preparing an even more aggressive attack on Fed independence :

Donald Trump 's allies are quietly drafting proposals that would attempt to erode the Federal Reserve's independence if the former president wins a second term, in the midst of a deepening divide among his advisers over how aggressively to challenge the central bank's authority .

Former Trump administration officials and other supporters of the presumptive GOP nominee have in recent months discussed a range of proposals, from incremental policy changes to a long-shot assertion that the president himself should play a role in setting interest rates…

The group of Trump allies argues that he should be consulted on interest-rate decisions , and the draft document recommends subjecting Fed regulations to White House review and more forcefully using the Treasury Department as a check on the central bank. The group also contends that Trump, if he returns to the White House, would have the authority to oust Jerome Powell as Fed chair before his four-year term ends in 2026, the people familiar with the matter said[.]

In fact, Trump seems to love nothing more than feuding with, and establishing dominance over, American institutions; this is simply one more example.

Forcing the Fed to lower interest rates, even in the face of high-ish inflation, would help Trump keep employment high for the duration of his term. It would also push down the government's interest costs, delaying the need for austerity. But the cost of those low interest rates would be higher inflation.

And as US businesses, investors, and households realized that the Fed had been permanently compromised and politicized, inflation expectations would likely rise, canceling out the hard work that Volcker and his successors did to convince Americans that the Fed is inherently hawkish.

A combination of tariffs, high and rising deficits, and monetary interference could push inflation back to 1970s levels. Larry Summers, who correctly predicted the inflation of 2021, is right to worry :

Summers sees the same danger. “It is difficult to predict the timing and the precise dynamics,” he told me, “but it is hard to imagine a policy package more likely to create stagflation” than measures that directly raise prices (through tariffs), undermine competition, enlarge deficits, and excessively expand the money supply. “There is a real risk during a Trump presidency that we would again see mortgage rates above 10 percent as inflation expectations rose and long-term interest rates increased,” he predicted.

In Trump's first term, he got lucky. Underlying inflationary pressures in the US were still fairly weak, deficits crept up but stayed under control, Trump's early tariffs had only a minor impact, and the Fed managed to resist Trump's initial attack on its independence. In a second term, he might get even luckier, but I wouldn't bet the farm on it.

And then there's the outside chance that a second Trump term could usher in not just painful and persistent inflation, but an actual economic catastrophe.

Could Trump cause hyperinflation?

No one really knows what causes some countries to explode into very high levels of inflation. But economists have a guess . Basically, the idea is that when the government becomes committed to running big permanent deficits, and the central bank becomes committed to permanently supporting that borrowing with money creation, everyone basically abandons the country's currency and its value collapses.

Some people think this only happens when countries lose wars or have some other kind of geopolitical instability. But in many hyperinflations in developing countries, there's no war or revolution involved — instead, the combination of infinite deficits and infinite deficit-supporting money creation is due to a country's own internal politics. In practice, this usually means that a country gets a populist leader who is committed to staying in power by handing out fiscal goodies to supporters and/or cronies, and who manages to force the monetary authority to support this strategy.

Could this pattern happen with Trump? It's not likely. America is such a big rich economy, and the dollar is such an important currency, that it would take a heck of a lot of macroeconomic meddling in order to turn it into Argentina or Venezuela. But it's not entirely out of the question, either. And the consequences of hyperinflation are so dire — Venezuelans were literally reduced to premodern living conditions in the 2010s — that it's worth worrying about even if the chance is small.

Now, this might sound silly to some people who lived through Trump's first term. There was no inflation under Trump the first time, why would we expect super-high inflation if Trump came back to power? But it's worth noting that in most episodes of hyperinflation, it takes a number of years under the fiscally irresponsible ruling regime for inflation to explode. Things look OK for a while, and then bam .

For example, take Hugo Chavez and his successor, Nicolas Maduro. Chavez became President of Venezuela in 2002, and died in 2013. It's pretty clear, in hindsight, that it was Chavez' failed economic policies — continued by Maduro — that eventually resulted in Venezuela's disastrous hyperinflation. But Venezuelan inflation looked like it was more or less under control until just before Chavez' death!

Or take Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a populist leader who has been in office since 2014 and was prime minister for eleven years before that. Erdogan's policy of constantly forcing the central bank to lower interest rates caused the currency to collapse and inflation to go to over 60% — not technically hyperinflation, but more than six times as high as US inflation in 2021-22.经济增长停滞了几年，直到2023年及时扭转低利率政策才稳定了局势。

但在2018年之前，土耳其自2004年以来通胀一直较低且稳定！埃尔多安就任总统已经四年了，他担任总理也已经十多年了，他的政策导致通货膨胀爆发。

这是我在特朗普和通胀方面最担心的。特朗普第一任期内稳定、平静的宏观经济形势，可能会让人们相信特朗普是一个负责任的宏观经济管家，为他在第二任期进行宏观经济纵火提供政治掩护。与查韦斯和埃尔多安——其他与本国机构不和的民粹主义领导人一样——特朗普可能会对美国宏观经济产生腐蚀作用，而其真正的损害并不明显，直到为时已晚。

莫迪可能还会做一些我一直希望看到的事情——建立更大的企业特区，放松印度著名的严厉监管。如果能做到更多就更好了，不过全国范围内推动放松对工业用地使用的管制也有好处。

但为了促进印度制造业的发展，莫迪需要做一件大事：让该国的女性就业。尽管教育、健康和交通有所改善，但印度女性劳动力参与率仍低至令人难以置信的37%，并且还在下降。据我所知，任何一个国家在建设世界级制造业时，都会充分利用大量从乡村到城市到工厂工作的女性，这是工业化的普遍特征。而女性流入城市也将有助于改善印度落后的城市化率。

因此，将印度妇女从农场转移到工厂应该是莫迪下个任期的首要任务。

（更新：莫迪的政党失去了一些席位，最终领导了一个联合政府，而不是获得绝对多数，这一事实应该会让你对印度的民主更有信心。印度经历了周期性的反自由主义浪潮——1970 年代的紧急状态是另一个例子但在分析印度的崛起时，我劝你不要认为它与纳伦德拉·莫迪是一致的，而且它的制度比任何一个人都大得多。）

2. 拜登在边境问题上采取强硬态度，但法院会允许他这么做吗？

从很多方面来说，乔·拜登都是人们记忆中最进步的总统——他投入了大量资金应对气候变化、免除大量学生债务、重振反垄断执法、推动跨性别者权利等等。但他也做了很多重要的保守派事情——开发水力压裂技术，将石油产量推至历史新高，试图增加街头警察的数量，等等。

现在，在多年来基本上忽视边境危机之后，拜登变得更强硬——可以说比特朗普更强硬。他试图通过一项严厉的边境法案，但共和党为了阻止拜登在选举年获胜而否决了该法案。现在拜登正在准备一项行政命令， 禁止人们在美墨边境申请庇护，除非流入量降至较低水平：

白宫告诉立法者，乔·拜登总统正准备签署一项行政命令，一旦入境口岸之间每日平均接触人数达到 2,500 人，该命令将关闭美墨边境的庇护申请，仅重新开放边境据几位知情人士透露，一旦这个数字下降到 1,500 人……行政命令可能会立即生效，因为每日数字比现在更高……

政府律师一直在计划利用《移民和国籍法》第 212(f) 条规定的行政权力，该法赋予总统广泛的权力，可以在被认为“损害”国家利益的情况下阻止某些移民进入美国。特朗普在担任总统期间对移民采取一些最严厉的行动时也采用了同样的法律依据。

进步团体已经准备在法庭上挑战行政命令。我不是法律专家，但我的猜测是，行政命令将被推翻，就像特朗普的那样。

这里的核心问题是，美国庇护法规定，如果你非法越境并向边境巡逻队自首，你就合法地有权请求庇护，就像你在入境口岸自我介绍一样。这并不意味着你会获得庇护——事实上，大多数涌入边境的人都不会获得庇护，因为他们实际上只是在寻找工作，而不是逃离战争或暴政。

但仅仅能够申请庇护就能带来很多好处。一方面，你的申请速度比在入境口岸等待要快得多——基本上，非法入境意味着你要插队。此外，您通常可以在美国等待庇护听证会。

换句话说，美国的庇护法激励移民非法越境。这实际上与开放边界并不是一回事，但向普通美国人解释其中的差异可能出人意料地困难。事实上，普通人在了解美国庇护法的这一关键方面时常常感到惊讶和愤怒：

这里显而易见的解决方案是修改美国法律，禁止非法居留者申请庇护（并修改允许非法居留者申请“暂缓递解出境”的法律，这与庇护类似）换句话说，解决方案是让国会修改美国法律，使其几乎完全符合拜登的行政命令所试图做的事情。

如果我们这样做，很多法律界的人会很不高兴，因为律师界有一个共同的观点，即申请庇护的权利是一项普遍人权。当然，即使我们按照我描述的方式改变法律，人们仍然可以在入境口岸申请庇护，尽管这会更困难、更危险。对一些人来说，人权要求我们允许人们非法越境申请庇护，从而使申请变得更加容易和安全。

但这种观点对于普通美国人来说可能没有什么意义。我们政府的一部分（我们的庇护法）应该鼓励外国人蔑视我们政府的另一部分（边境），这种想法似乎有点荒谬。美国人普遍对边境危机感到愤怒，他们对那些违法者并不抱有热情。移民对美国的未来极其重要，要保持对强劲移民的广泛、持久的民众支持，就需要制止非法越境的大规模混乱洪流。

不管怎样，真正的问题是为什么国会还没有尝试这样做。想必民主党人在某种程度上对那些希望让申请庇护变得尽可能容易的进步活动团体心存感激。共和党人可能只是想保留边界问题，这样他们就有理由抨击民主党人。无论如何，只要国会不改变庇护法，拜登的强硬行动能否持久解决问题就值得怀疑。

3.有关气候的好消息

那里有很多气候厄运论，而且这是非常无用和愚蠢的。但我可以原谅即使是理性的人感到有点悲观，因为地球气候的命运很大程度上不在他们所居住的西方国家的手中：

中国无疑是这里最重要的参与者，因为它几乎是世界上唯一建造新燃煤电厂的国家，而且正在建造相当多的燃煤电厂。我推荐劳里·米利维尔塔 (Lauri Myllyvirta) 的这篇精彩采访，了解为什么尽管中国建设了如此多的可再生能源，但本已巨大的排放量仍在上升：

但还有一线希望。 Myllyvirta 有一篇很棒的博客文章，显示中国上个月的排放量实际上有所下降：

米利维尔塔写道，造成这种情况的最大原因是中国经济放缓。但太阳能和风能的持续快速增长也开始产生影响：

近年来中国排放增长的主要推动力是电力行业……主要原因……是电力行业排放增速大幅放缓。由于太阳能和风力发电的强劲增长，该行业的排放量同比仅增长了1%……虽然电力行业排放稳定，但3月份排放量减少的最大来源是钢铁需求的持续下降建筑行业的水泥……钢铁产量下降了 8%，钢厂使用的主要燃料——炼焦煤的产量也随之下降。水泥产量大幅下降，同比下降22%。

因此，彭博新能源财经现在认为全球排放量已经见顶，并将从现在开始加速下降。

这还不够快，不足以使世界免遭严重伤害。但这应该是消除周围浮夸的厄运和忧郁情绪的一剂解药。

4. 非营利组织正在让美国窒息；美国终于醒悟了吗？

一年前，我写了一篇文章，谴责美国城市和州政府，尤其是进步地区的政府，将基本职能外包给非营利组织：

将政府职能外包给非营利组织是私有化的一种形式。重要的是，这是进步人士可以接受的一种私有化形式。但非营利组织几乎没有责任，导致成本膨胀和服务质量下降，并让不择手段的非营利组织高管将纳税人的钱装进自己的口袋。他们很容易与政治赞助人陷入腐败关系。人们只需看看旧金山就可以看到非营利组织政府的负面后果，旧金山制定了法律，以赋予非营利组织最大的影响力。

幸运的是，越来越多的美国人开始意识到这场治理灾难。我开始看到更多的专家赞同我对非营利工业综合体的警告。例如， 以下是《美国事务》中的乔纳森·爱尔兰：

当有人听到非营利这个词时，他们会认为这样的组织是为了公共利益而工作……听到某个东西是“非营利”时，立即给人一种该组织值得信赖的感觉，并且运营该组织的人是受慈善议程驱动的……因此，非营利组织获得任何其他形式的私人公司都不会享有的疑点利益……

结果……很少有足够的监督来保证他们正在做我们付钱给他们做的事……金钱的花费方式会让纳税人感到震惊，他们辛苦赚来的钱实际上被从他们身上偷走了。自以为是地宣称自己是无家可归者服务提供者的非营利组织，为了增加自己的资金，积极游说，使无家可归现象变得更糟……而非营利组织的高管，即那些声称目的不是赚钱的机构的负责人，却赚了数百万美元。美元，而灾难性地未能提供我们付钱给他们提供的公共服务……随着这一切的发生，相关非营利组织从国税局获得税收减免……

美国[进步的]城市地区正在不断提高税收，以资助公共服务……但这些税收收入随后被浪费在……不负责任的非营利组织上，这些组织的活动对解决问题几乎没有作用……税收随之飙升当地生活水平的崩溃和公共服务的衰退……非营利组织无法妥善管理服务导致欧洲对第三世界国家的能力征税。居民们不知道问题出在哪里：他们不知道他们的税款流向了被定罪的重罪犯的“暴力干扰者”；他们不知道经济适用房非营利组织使用纳税人的钱来游说反对经济适用房；他们不知道由于对非营利组织的监管不足，资金被错误分配。

爱尔兰接着描述了 TODCO 的臭名昭著的案例，这是一家旧金山非营利组织，本应为穷人提供住房服务，但提供的服务却很少，同时将纳税人的大部分资金花在 A）高管工资上，以及 B）游说反对建造新住房。相当吵闹。

但至少人们开始觉醒。一些进步人士，例如威尔·斯坦西尔，已经意识到非营利性私有化对整个进步项目构成的致命威胁。当然，另一种选择是通过加强公务员队伍来恢复国家能力，并让官僚接管许多现在被外包的职能。

5. 为什么紧缩时代即将到来

一段时间以来，我一直认为美国将不得不很快从赤字支出转向紧缩政策。原因很简单，就是利率。利率在很长一段时间里都处于很低的水平，但现在为了对抗通货膨胀，利率又有点高了。这提高了美国债务的偿还成本：

目前，政府显然希望加息是暂时的。短期政府借款的激增显然是利率很快会回落的赌注。

但利率可能不会回落至美国和世界大部分地区在 2000 年代和 2010 年代享有的水平。 5% 可能不是新常态，但有理由相信 0% 也不可能出现。 CEA 前首席经济学家厄尼·特德斯基 (Ernie Tedeschi) 令人信服地指出，由于各种原因，“自然利率”（通胀与增长平衡的利率）注定会上升。

其中一些理由是好的。更快的经济增长会提高自然利率，因为它会增加潜在的经济投资回报。生产率的快速增长，加上移民的增加，让我们有理由对美国的经济增长持乐观态度：

投资者可能会抬高国债市场收益率，从而推高[自然利率]，原因之一是预期生产率增长是否上升，这反过来意味着消费增长更强劲……[并且]自 2022 年以来，有证据表明，劳动力供给可能比通常测得的还要多。这种扩张的主要驱动力是高于预期的移民。

但也可能存在负面原因。美国国债通常被认为是金融体系中的“安全资产”，但如果美国政治不稳定，投资者可能会开始要求更高的风险溢价来借钱给山姆大叔：

[自然利率]的上升也可能部分反映了过去十年美国较高的政治风险，与财政风险无关。最近的一项估计发现，以股票风险溢价计算，美国的政治风险在过去八年里上升了 20-25 个基点。

泰德斯基还指出，高赤字会导致利率上升，从而使高赤字更难以维持。

无论如何，有很多理由认为利率可能不会回到原来的 0%。如果是这样的话，那么即使利率定在2%或3%而不是5-6%，国债的利息成本也将大大高于以前。这将迎来一个紧缩时代。

“你想知道我们的秘密吗？/哎呀，抱歉，我们没有”——东京事变

我最近写作的一个主题是与中国的战争威胁。我不认为冲突无论如何都是不可避免的，但这种可能性已经足够了，为此做好准备必须成为美国和其他地方政策制定者的主要关注点。但在过去的两个月里，很多人告诉我，我应该去中国，以便更好地了解其地缘政治意图。有人告诉我，如果我去那里，我就会意识到中国并不真正想要战争：

事实上，我实际上去过中国几次——最近一次是 2019 年的香港之旅，最终我逃离了警察的追捕。那么为什么人们认为再次去会改变我对地缘政治事件的看法呢？

告诉我这些事情的四个人都不是专业的中国骗子；他们都不是专业的中国骗子。他们都是我认识的人，都是我尊敬的人。他们只是真诚地相信，去中国旅行并与那里的人们见面是了解中国人想要什么的好方法。

现在，这里明显的对立之处是，一个国家人民的意志与治理国家的人民的意志并不相同。习近平并不代表普通中国人，事实上，除了极少数情况外，他甚至可能根本不听普通中国人的意见。正如赫尔曼·戈林在纽伦堡受审时所说，普通民众通常不会在战争后产生欲望；当他们的领导人决定将他们拖入战争时，他们只是支持战争。

在上海闲逛，你不会看到包围台湾的军舰舰队，也不会被允许参观以二战以来前所未有的速度生产军事装备的大型工厂。在餐馆里与商人交谈，在夜总会里与年轻人交谈。不会告诉你太多关于政治局和党国其他机关闭门谈论的内容。所有关于战争与和平的相关决定都将由你作为游客永远不会见到的人做出。

所以我的朋友们在这里显然是错误的。但他们相信旅游能够传达对一个国家及其人民的深刻了解，这让我思考：你能从海外旅行中真正学到多少东西？

为什么旅游业是了解其他国家的薄弱工具

事实上，我一直是海外生活的大力倡导者。早在 2021 年，我就写过一篇文章，认为其他国家的生活可以帮助你认识到自己国家的缺陷和优势：

但这与说你可以通过旅行来了解一个国家不同，原因有很多。

首先，看到其他国家并不等于了解他们，尽管这都是有价值的活动。如果你去日本看到他们拥有令人惊叹的火车系统，它会激发你思考“为什么我们在美国没有一个很棒的火车系统？”，甚至“美国如何才能获得更好的火车？” 。但它不会告诉你为什么日本有这么棒的火车。它不会告诉您日本的火车系统是如何建造的，或者为什么建造。 It will not tell you how much it cost or how easy it is to maintain. It will not tell you about any political problems Japan's government had to overcome in order to get the trains built, and so on.

It's good to know that other countries can do things differently, but that's only the first step in learning about those differences.

Second, a trip of a week or even three weeks doesn't give you enough time to learn much about a place. Living overseas, especially for multiple years, will allow you to develop deep relationships with the people there — work colleagues, close friends, long-term romantic partners, etc. It will also let you see how people live in their day-to-day life — what their workday looks like, what their house looks like. You'll experience the frustrations and the inefficiencies as well as the conveniences. You'll understand the dreams and the heartbreaks and the day-to-day pleasures.

As a tourist, you will learn very little about any of those things. You'll walk around and see the buildings but you won't know who lives or works there. You'll chat with people in restaurants and bars but you won't learn their secrets. You'll experience the surface of a place but you won't perceive the depths.

In my experience, tourists also tend to make mistakes about countries' economic situations from looking at the public buildings and infrastructure. Tokyo, for example, is a visual marvel , with forests of newly built buildings, immaculate shops and restaurants, and beautiful parks. But only once you live in Japan for a while do you realize that many Japanese people are quietly falling into poverty .去上海或深圳可以欺骗您以为中国是世界上最富有的国家，而不是中等收入的国家 - 中国正偏离世界历史上最大的建筑繁荣，而1级城市中的一切都在其资本折旧周期的开始。

当然，在一个地方呆在一个地方并不能保证您会深入了解它 - 有些人可以在一个国家生活了十年，对此几乎没有洞察力。但是，如果您只在短时间内访问，就会有很多陷阱和理解障碍。

例如，如果您不花太多时间在一个地方，那么您遇到的人将受到选择效果的严重主导，尤其是如果您不会说本地语言。如果您以美国游客的身份去中国或寻找投资公司，那么您的对话往往会与讲英语的西方中国人进行。喜欢外国和说外语的人并不总是代表他们所居住的社会。如果有高度民族主义的中国人坐在谈论他们想要与美国战争的方式，他们可能不会参加您的火锅派对。

最后，以我的经验，人们倾向于通过其先入为主的观念和预先存在的刻板印象来看到外国。在2021年的帖子中，我写道：

另一个陷阱是倾向于通过您自己先入为主的刻板印象看到其他文化。我已经看到一些西方人将无限的创造力和对日本街头时尚场景的自我表达方式解释为某种形式的一致性，仅仅是因为他们一直被告知日本是一个“集体主义者”国家（即使发现了调查从1980年代中期开始，日本比美国变得更加独立。我的一个澳大利亚朋友对看到日本人在火车上戴着口罩（嘿）表示厌恶，以为它是从挑剔的细菌恐惧症中出现的。我们必须解释说，这些人本身就感冒了，并认真地试图防止将其细菌传播给他人。

它从来没有停止过让我惊讶的是，来自美国和其他盎格鲁国家的多少人倾向于依靠刻板印象来理解日本。其中的一部分可能是由于露丝·本尼迪克特（Ruth Benedict）的《菊花》（Chrysanthemum）和剑和类似书籍所致，但是保守的日本思想家在理论上对文化的独特性进行理论时经常采用一厢情愿的思想，也必须在这里承担一些责任。

我应该提到的是，许多这些刻板印象都是完全错误的。最令人难以置信的例子是“罪恶与羞耻文化”的概念 - 本尼迪克特写道，西方人遵守他们的内部良心（“罪恶感”），而日本人则受到社会制裁的威胁（“羞耻”）的动机。许多美国人仍然相信这一点，但这是完整而完全胡说八道的。

心理学研究和随后的人类学研究都与本尼迪克特的理论相矛盾，这表明日本人受到内gui和羞耻感的强烈动机。但是，您甚至不需要同行评审的文学才能知道这是胡说八道 - 即使没有人看着，日本人也一贯做正确的事情。一个典型的例子是日本人如何将损失的现金转向，而不是为自己保留，即使周围没有人会知道他们是否保留了这笔现金。 1几乎没有日本人乱扔垃圾，即使他们可以在没有被抓住的情况下做到这一点。日本人要小心地将垃圾放在正确的垃圾桶中，即使没有人会看到他们把它放在错误的地方。等等。

如果您问日本人，为什么当没人看时他们会做正确的事情，他们会告诉您他们担心给别人带来不便或伤害他人的不便，这是有罪良心的经典标志。

然而，一些西方人几乎拼命地拼命地遵守本尼迪克特的错误刻板印象。当我向外籍人士指出现金的同伴如何表明日本社会是出于内gui的动机，有些人承认了这一点，而另一些人则坚持认为这不是“内gui”，而是“内在化的羞耻” - 他们基本上发明了一个新的术语，与本尼迪克特的最初描述完全不一致，以使自己相信自己的刻板印象从未错过。

对于许多人来说，这些文化刻板印象是认知风暴不确定的舒适港口。当面对一些令人恐惧的新颖的东西，例如一种外国文化时，我们努力地为我们放心我们已经理解它的任何事情。

而且，由于这些人在旅行时会随身携带他们的刻板印象，所以他们学到的任何课程都会通过该镜头过滤。那些相信中国人是一个和平，商业的种族而不是一个战争的人，他们会随着这一想法的加强而偏离中国的对话。 2那些以中国的刻板印象为军事偏执的社会，他们渴望为“屈辱的世纪”报仇的人可能会加剧这种想法。

即使是聪明的游客也很容易归结为这些东西。例如，博客的作者蒂姆·乌尔班（Tim Urban）在2014年去日本旅行，并重申了一堆疲倦的文化刻板印象，他在这个相当有趣的图表中总结了这一点：

由于他自己的承认，Urban不会说日语，只能与一些日本人进行粗略的交流。但是仅仅两个星期之后，城市以某种方式设法就日本人得出了非常深刻的结论，包括存在着西方人永远无法渗透的广阔的“内心心理”。

经过两周的订购食物和询问指示，城市如何使日本人如此深入地看到日本人？明显的答案是他没有。取而代之的是，他对他所看到的内容的理解来自他所读过的东西，以及与其他西方人的讨论。例如，他写道：

这种社会和谐在日本文化中根深蒂固，至关重要的是，至关重要的是，在日本发生负面互动是社会灾难性的，导致您“失去面部”，这是一种痛苦的经历。

这直接从菊花和剑出来。但是Urban认为他设法从该国的两个星期来推断出来！这就是先入为主的力量。

我不想在这里对蒂姆·厄本（Tim Urban）或喜欢去中国旅行的朋友们太努力。去新的地方并形成印象绝对没有错。我这样做。好有趣！但是，您不应该愚弄自己认为这可以预测一个国家的经济或地缘政治命运。

为什么你还是应该旅行

但是，在这一切之后，我想强调，我认为国际旅行是一件非常好的事情，您实际上可以从中学到很多东西。那你能学到什么？

首先，就像在海外生活一样，旅行可以帮助您了解自己的国家。如果您在一个地方长大并生活在那里，您可能不会想象任何其他生活方式是可能的。旅行将使您失去那个概念。许多美国人前往日本，希望美国可以拥有更好的火车系统，或者没有使您脱鞋的机场安全。或者他们去阿姆斯特丹，并希望美国更适合自行车。或者他们去新加坡，并希望美国能够有很多住房和超低犯罪。观察其他国家的优势告诉您，更好的事情可以回到家。

另一方面，旅行可以帮助您更多地欣赏自己的国家。如果您认为普通美国人的生活是有物质贫困的生活，那么前往欧洲或日本的旅行可能会让您意识到，即使大多数其他富裕国家的生活水平也远远落后于美国。如果您从未停止考虑美国杂货店的惊人多么令人惊叹，那么在质量和选择方面，访问另一个国家的超市可能会增加您对Safeway，Kroger和（尤其是） HEB的欣赏。如果您认为美国是一个充满破坏性骚乱和抗议活动的不守规矩的国家，那么您应该在法国度过一些时间。

旅行的另一个原因是，即使您从未真正理解自己所看到的东西，也简单地将自己暴露在不同的文化上会使您不太害怕一般的差异。 Cao，Galinsky和Maddux（2014）发现了许多具有相当可靠的研究设计的研究，所有这些都同意旅行增加了社会信任：

五项研究检查了外国经验对广义信任的广度和深度的影响。研究1发现，广度（旅行的国家数量），但没有（旅行时间）的外国旅行体验的深度（旅行时间）预测了决策游戏中的信任行为。研究2和3通过实验操纵对外国体验的广度与深度的关注，从而对广义信任建立了因果影响。研究4使用纵向设计来确定广泛的外国旅行经验增加了普遍的信任。研究5探讨了基本过程，发现关注差异而不是访问的国家之间的相似性对于产生更大的广义信任至关重要。在五项研究中，使用各种方法（相关，实验室实验和纵向），样本（美国和中文）以及操作（信任游戏和广义信任量表），我们发现了外国旅行经验的广度与广义信任之间存在牢固的关系。

这可能只是接触假设的一种形式，它说与您不同的人与您不同，这会让您对他们更有利。大城市比小城镇更自由的原因也可能是相同的原因 - 世界主义会滋生宽容。

出国旅行也可以帮助您分解一些先入之见。土耳其 - 或至少是伊斯坦布尔 - 感觉比我在精神上预期的更丰富，更现代。巴黎人比我预期的要温暖得多。德国的城市化不及我预期的。这些更新并不是什么令人震惊的，但是它们确实帮助我获得了更多完整，最新的了解当今世界的样子。

最后，即使海外旅行并没有给您回答为什么其他国家的样子，它们也可以激励您开始提出问题。前往台湾的旅行让我想知道为什么街道与日本的布置如此不同，为什么建筑物不那么新颖，等等。前往爱尔兰让我想知道这个国家几乎在一夜之间从几个世纪的贫困到物质舒适和财富。前往新加坡的旅行使我想知道他们如何设法建造如此多的住房，如何变得比美国更富有，以及尽管建筑物的侧面有一堆植物，但他们如何设法设法没有任何虫子。等等。

您可以学习这些问题的答案 - 它只需要时间和研究。

至于中国，我绝对同意我的朋友们，人们应该在那里旅行并亲眼看到它。不，它不会告诉您他们是否要发动战争。但是，您可以乘坐出色的高速火车，用一个应用程序付款，通过机器人将东西送到您家门口，并在建筑物的侧面看到很多漂亮的LED。如果您是美国人，您可以看到一个实际上建造事物的国家的有益例子，而不是让当地的尼米比斯强迫建筑环境陷入崩溃的废墟。

您可能也可以吃一些漂亮的食物。

昨天，正如您可能听说的那样，唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）在纽约被定罪34个重罪。所有费用都涉及伪造业务记录。基本上，特朗普与色情明星睡着，让他的律师付钱给色情明星，以保持安静，然后将付款错误地标记为法律费用，以保持整个事情的安静。宣判后，特朗普现在将开始漫长的上诉程序。

无论如何，特朗普只是被定罪的罪行并不是我个人将任何人送入监狱的那种事情，而且直觉上没有感觉像是重罪的水平。

换句话说，特朗普的信念只是强化了我目前处于重要历史枢纽的看法。
